docs.lead_paragraph: Yes, Virginia, there are entrepreneurs in Congress - 11 of them, in fact, were elected to the 111th Congress,* as best as we can determine. And, whether Republican or Democrat, they overwhelmingly voted against the health care reform bill that passed late Saturday night. Here's a roll call:

headline.main: Entrepreneurs in Congress Say No to Health Care Reform

docs.abstract: And whether they are Republicans or Democrats seems to have made little difference.
docs.snippet: And whether they are Republicans or Democrats seems to have made little difference.

docs.lead_paragraph: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.
docs.abstract: My brief rant about "famously" two weeks ago prompted readers and colleagues to share complaints about other words that might deserve a rest. Some of these, too, are familiar refrains, but worth a reminder.
docs.snippet: My brief rant about "famously" two weeks ago prompted readers and colleagues to share complaints about other words that might deserve a rest. Some of these, too, are familiar refrains, but worth a reminder.

docs.lead_paragraph: PBS's "Frontline" offers a timely repeat of a 2008 program called "Sick Around the World" (PBS, 9 p.m. on most stations). In one fast-moving hour, it examines the health care and insurance systems of five countries, including Britain, Japan and Germany, and makes the case that supporters of health-care reform in America have failed to make over the last year. A review of the program is here.

headline.main: What to Watch Tuesday: Health Care Elsewhere, 'NCIS' and Ghost-Hunting

docs.lead_paragraph: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. phoned him midafternoon on Friday. A few hours later, in the early evening, President Obama called, carrying the same message. The House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, had been pushing him for days. So had the House majority leader, Steny H. Hoyer.

headline.main: Why McMahon Voted No on Health Care Bill

docs.abstract: Representative Michael E. McMahon, a first-term congressman from Staten Island, was the only House member from New York City to vote against the health care overhaul.
docs.snippet: Representative Michael E. McMahon, a first-term congressman from Staten Island, was the only House member from New York City to vote against the health care overhaul.

docs.lead_paragraph: Party leaders’ flexibility on issues like abortion and a public option has kept the health bill on track, but it has also left many liberals off balance.
